citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
Changes were made to procedures conducted on non-human primates without securing IACUC approval in advance. On
June 10, 2024 and July 8, 2024, two cohorts of Cynomolgus macaques, consisting of a total of 16 adults, were kept in
activity monitoring jackets for 4-6 days, several days past the protocol’s maximum time of 48 hours. However, no animals
experienced adverse effects due to this oversight.
Failure to secure IACUC approval for modifications to an approved protocol prior to enacting those changes does not
afford the IACUC the opportunity to review the changes regarding the care and use of animals in ongoing activities and
either approve, require modifications in, or withhold approval of the changes.
With respect to activities involving animals, the IACUC, as an agent of the research facility, shall: review and approve,
require modification in (to secure approval), or withhold approval of proposed significant changes regarding the care and
use of animals in ongoing activities.

Handling of animals at the facility was not done as expeditiously and carefully as possible, leading to the death of a non-
human primate under anesthesia, and three non-human primates receiving injuries due to a fight.
On May 9, 2024, one (1) adult female cynomolgus macaque was sedated, anesthetized, and intubated as part of a routine
CT imaging procedure. Supplemental flow-by oxygen was started but mistakenly connected to the animal’s endotracheal
tube, leading to excessive positive pressure, ultimately causing respiratory failure and death of the animal, despite
emergency interventions.
On November 2, 2024, animal care staff accidentally opened two non-human primate enclosures, allowing a singly-
housed adult male cynomolgus macaque to enter the enclosure of two (2) adult pair-housed male cynomolgus macaques.
This led to a fight between the macaques, resulting in all three receiving multiple external injuries. The facility immediately
took action to re-separate the males into their respective enclosures and administer veterinary care.
Failure to handle animals appropriately can lead to trauma, behavioral stress, and physical harm.
Correct by ensuring that all animals are handled as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not
cause trauma, overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.
Correct by end of business, November 8, 2024. The facility took measures to identify the factors leading to the anesthetic
death and have implemented several corrective actions to prevent recurrence.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Rachel Perez-Baum, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.31(c)(7)  Repeat
   
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC). 
Changes were made to procedures conducted on non-human primates without securing IACUC approval in advance. On 
June 10, 2024 and July 8, 2024, two cohorts of Cynomolgus macaques, consisting of a total of 16 adults, were kept in 
activity monitoring jackets for 4-6 days, several days past the protocol’s maximum time of 48 hours. However, no animals 
experienced adverse effects due to this oversight.  
 
Failure to secure IACUC approval for modifications to an approved protocol prior to enacting those changes does not 
afford the IACUC the opportunity to review the changes regarding the care and use of animals in ongoing activities and 
either approve, require modifications in, or withhold approval of the changes.  
 
With respect to activities involving animals, the IACUC, as an agent of the research facility, shall: review and approve, 
require modification in (to secure approval), or withhold approval of proposed significant changes regarding the care and 
use of animals in ongoing activities. 
2.38(f)(1)  Critical
   
Miscellaneous. 
Handling of animals at the facility was not done as expeditiously and carefully as possible, leading to the death of a non-
human primate under anesthesia, and three non-human primates receiving injuries due to a fight.  
 
On May 9, 2024, one (1) adult female cynomolgus macaque was sedated, anesthetized, and intubated as part of a routine 
CT imaging procedure. Supplemental flow-by oxygen was started but mistakenly connected to the animal’s endotracheal 
tube, leading to excessive positive pressure, ultimately causing respiratory failure and death of the animal, despite 
emergency interventions.  
 
On November 2, 2024, animal care staff accidentally opened two non-human primate enclosures, allowing a singly-
housed adult male cynomolgus macaque to enter the enclosure of two (2) adult pair-housed male cynomolgus macaques. 
This led to a fight between the macaques, resulting in all three receiving multiple external injuries. The facility immediately

took action to re-separate the males into their respective enclosures and administer veterinary care.  
 
Failure to handle animals appropriately can lead to trauma, behavioral stress, and physical harm.  
 
Correct by ensuring that all animals are handled as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not 
cause trauma, overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort.  
 
Correct by end of business, November 8, 2024. The facility took measures to identify the factors leading to the anesthetic 
death and have implemented several corrective actions to prevent recurrence. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Rachel Perez-Baum, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
